awd_titl_txt: Collaborative research: Multi-disciplinary investigation of the links between volcanism, marine redox, and mass extinction during the Late Triassic and Early Jurassic
awd_abstract_narration:
The end-Triassic mass extinction that occurred ~210 million years ago was one of the largest in Earth’s history. Understanding the timeline of environmental stresses that led to this event and similar events, provide important context for understanding current and future global change. Our current understanding is limited, mostly because of the limited geographic coverage of data and most of exisiting studies narrowly focus on the time interval of the mass extinction itself. This study will address these gaps by investigating a record of environmental and biologic change that is recorded in the fossils and chemistry of sedimentary rocks now located in the Wrangell Mountains of Alaska. This unique sequence of rocks represent marine sediments that were deposited in an understudied part of the planet — the Paleo-Pacific or Panthalassic Ocean. Additionally, this project will enable the mentorship and scientific training of graduate and undergraduate students and will involve a number of public outreach activities that highlight the interdisciplinary nature of geoscience research used to tackle big scientific problems like the causes of mass extinctions. Museum and traveling exhibits will be developed and the project team will engage in visits to high school science classrooms and public science open houses.

This study will use a multi-disciplinary approach to develop a more holistic understanding of the geographic and temporal record of marine diversity and redox conditions within the oceans before, during, and after the end-Triassic mass extinction from an understudied Panthalassic Ocean site. This will be accomplished by studying the long-term Late Triassic through Early Jurassic time interval recorded in the McCarthy Formation in the Wrangell Mountains of Alaska. Paleontological data will be collected for four major taxonomic groups (ammonoids, bivalves, conodonts, corals); geochemical data (carbon, sulfur, and thallium isotopes; iron speciation; redox-sensitive trace metal abundances); and uranium-lead dates from ash beds. Through the careful integration of the paleontological, geochemical, and geochronological results, the proposed study will provide a framework for understanding the relationship between the biotic, marine redox, and carbon cycle changes. Results of the proposed study will be used to directly assess and temporally constrain the timing of (1) marine diversity losses and recovery, (2) local and global environmental changes, and (3) the potential factors that led to mass extinction and allowed for faunal recovery during the Late Triassic to Early Jurassic.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The broad goal of this study was to investigate the record of biologic and environmental change before, during, and after the end-Triassic mass extinction event that happened approximately 201 million years ago. Most of the studies of this event have focus on sedimentary rocks that provide a record of the time immediately before, during, and immediately after the extinction. They have also focused on sedimentary rocks that were deposited in only one ocean during this time: the ancient Tethys Ocean. This means it’s less clear what was happening during this event on other parts of the planet.

This study sought to fill these gaps by investigating rocks found at Grotto Creek in Wrangell-St. Elias National Park in Alaska. These sedimentary rock layers represent sediment that was deposited in the ancient Panthalassic (Paleo-Pacific) Ocean, and they record the time starting approximately 20 million years before the extinction to 10 million years after.

The major scientific goals of the project were to: (1) determine how the timing and magnitude of mass extinction varies between the Panthalassic and Tethys oceans, (2) whether there are changes in the oxygenation of seawater on the local (small) and global (large) scales during Late Triassic to Early Jurassic periods, specifically during the end-Triassic mass extinction, and (3) whether the extinction and environmental changes in the Panthalassic Ocean are tied to the large volcanic eruptions that has been are thought to have caused mass extinction.

The focus of the Virginia Team was to document changes in the chemistry of the rock layers found at Grotto Creek, which recorded changes in the environment when these rocks were deposited as sediment on the ancient seafloor. Overall, the changes in the chemistry of these rocks indicate several changes occurred in the environment before, during, and after the mass extinction. These include major changes to both the global and regional carbon cycle as documented the different stable isotopes of carbon. These findings aid in our understanding of local and global signals preserved in the Late Triassic-Early Jurassic carbon isotope records and improves our ability to link changes in the carbon cycle more precisely to the end-Triassic mass extinction. Changes in the iron and nitrogen chemistry of the rock layers at Grotto Creek indicate that the bottom waters had much less oxygen throughout the Late Triassic and Early Jurassic and were deposited under an oxygen minimum zone (OMZ) in Panthalassic Ocean. These data suggest that the OMZ changed in size and became more oxygen deficient. They also show that the OMZ occasionally contained sulfide and expanded shallow waters column just before, during after the end-Triassic mass extinction. These data indicate a role for loss of oxygen in the Panthalassic Ocean in the marine crises that occurred during the Late Triassic and Early Jurassic.

The award to-date has produced two peer reviewed journal articles, one master’s thesis, and seven presentations at international conferences. Three more journal articles are currently in preparation with at the end of the award.

This project had three types of broader impacts activities targeted to have an impact beyond basic science: (1) mentorship and training of graduate and undergraduate students; (2) facilitating undergraduate research experiences; and (3) public outreach.

 This award supported the mentorship, training, and research work of a Ph.D., master’s, and four undergraduate students at Virginia Tech. Four of these students are women and two are from groups underrepresented in STEM. These students gained research experience in fieldwork, geochemistry laboratory, or both during the project, as well as experience presenting their research at conferences. One of the undergraduates, after graduating, continued at Virginia Tech as a master’s student and continued working on this project. This student successfully defended her thesis during the project and went on to enroll as a Ph.D. student at the University of Wisconsin. Two of the other undergraduate students successfully graduated with bachelor’s degrees — one has entered STEM work force working with an environmental monitoring laboratory, and the other went on to pursue a master’s degree at Eastern Carolina University. The other undergraduate and Ph.D. student continue to work in the PI laboratory and will graduate in the coming year.

 This award also supported several outreach activities including five virtual classroom visits, a podcast episode with Curious Conversations, and a video by Virginia Tech News Team featuring the supported research project. The virtual classroom visits lasted 45-60 minutes and involved speaking to elementary to high school aged students with the Skype-a-Scientist program. Before these visits, the students listened to the podcast episode and watched the video about the project. The presentation and discussion with the students that followed focused on pathways to becoming a scientist, how geoscientists reconstruct the past climate and environmental history of our planet, and how that can tell us how it may change in the future.
